Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Upgrading laboratory facilities and experiential education at the Cape Eleuthera Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
Florida Atlantic University (FAU) is awarded a planning grant that will enable marine scientists and students to collaborate with the Cape Eleuthera Institute (CEI) and The Island School (IS) on the island of Eleuthera in the Bahamas for research and teaching purposes. CEI and IS are supported by the Cape Eleuthera Foundation (CEF), a U.S. 501c3 organization. This planning effort will bring together a broad and representative External Panel of marine scientists to join with the PI and Co-PIs in detailing changes in and additions to the existing laboratory and teaching facilities of CEI/IS to serve as many research and teaching interests of U.S. scientists as possible. Planning efforts will emphasize the infrastructure requisite to the study of marine ecosystems and to enhance experiential education. The collaboration with CEI/IS, a stable marine research and teaching campus, will free FAU from having to purchase lands and create facilities anew. U.S. scientists will have access to modernized research / teaching facilities at a reduced fee schedule according to our current Memorandum of Understanding.

This award is a significant step toward expanding and strengthening the infrastructure and training for societally relevant STEM research and undergraduate / graduate student training in South Florida and across the nation. Florida Atlantic University is an extremely diverse institution, and underrepresented minority students from South Florida and future US citizens from the Bahamas and the greater Caribbean will be involved in this training. The infrastructure development plan made possible by this award has the potential to provide the facilities to recruit and train a highly diverse cohort of students who can then add their unique perspectives to STEM areas important to the nation. For more information about CEI and IS visit their websites at http://www.ceibahamas.org and http://www.islandschool.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

 

The National Science Foundation - Field Station and Marine Laboratories (NSF-FSML) program awarded a planning grant (NSF Award #1318234; $ 24,226.00 June 15, 2013 to May 31, 2104) titled Upgrading laboratory facilities and experiential education at the Cape Eleuthera Institute (CEI) to Florida Atlantic University (FAU). FAU and CEI are collaborating on this project in order to expand the marine research capabilities of both organizations.

The planning process brought together the principal investigator (PI) Dr. J. William Louda (FAU) with three co-principal investigators: Dr. Brian Lapointe of Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute (HBOI) of FAU; Dr. Dave Philipp, Director of The Illinois Fisheries Genetics Laboratory, Illinois Natural History Survey-University of Illinois and a Board Member of the CEI Advisory Board; and Mr. Aaron Shultz, the Director of Research at CEI. In addition to the principals, seven well known American marine scientists were recruited and served as an External Panel.

The first stage involved visits to other marine laboratories in order to assess what works and what other laboratories feel that they need to improve. The following laboratories were visited: The Gerace Research Center of the college of the Bahamas on San Salvador Island, The Central Caribbean Marine Institute on Little Cayman Island, the Interagency (US-DOI, USGS, SFWMD) Florida Bay Laboratory on Key Largo-Florida, the Keys Marine Laboratory on Long Key-Florida, the Rosentiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences of the University of Miami (Florida), HBOI-FAU and the Gumbo Limbo Nature Center of FAU in Boca Raton-Florida. A no (grant) cost visit to the Scripps Institute of Oceanography in LaJolla California was made by the PI while at a scientific meeting in San Diego. Having assessed the capabilities of each station and taking notes during extended conversations with station directors and staff, we then moved on to stage two. Stage two was a site visit to the CEI-Island School (IS) facility on Eleuthera. All eleven participants were present for this four-day event. During this visit, all participants toured the facility, made notes and thought about how their specific research and experiential education could work at the existing or expanded CEI-IS facility. Tours of representative environmental sites were included to allow participants to evaluate the potential for natural resource research on Eleuthera and its marine habitats. We then conducted a one day workshop on what was needed to make CEI one of the best marine field stations in this hemisphere.

This planning process concluded that The Cape Eleuthera Institute (CEI) needs to go beyond studying individual organisms or species to examining processes at the ecosystem level. CEI will then be better positioned to contribute to ecosystem conservation and restoration efforts in the Bahamas as well as globally. Significant Intellectual Merit derives from expanding CEI emphasis and mission to encompass an ‘ecosystem approach’ within the pristine nature of the marine environments and latitudinal positioning of CEI provide for excellent comparative studies with the Florida Keys as well as the greater Caribbean.

To accomplish this goal, CEI should provide enough state-of-the-art collection (e.g. boats, SCUBS, nets, traps), analytical capabilities (e.g. water chemistry, nutrients, chlorophyll) and storage facilities (e.g. ultracold freezer) to serve the various in-house and visiting research groups that conduct studies and education at CEI/IS.
